docs.lead_paragraph: Adults are far more likely than their children to think that it is embarrassing for teenagers to admit to being virgins, and in fact teenagers wish their parents were a bit bolder in advising them about whether to have sex, according to a national study being released today. The study, by the National Campaign to Prevent Teen Pregnancy, a nonprofit group in Washington, shows teenagers and adults diverging on the topic of teenage sex: how many teenagers are having it, the importance of having it, and the influences for or against having it.

headline.main: Teenagers Want More Advice From Parents on Sex, Study Says

docs.abstract: National Campaign to Prevent Teen Pregnancy report shows adults and teens are split on topic of teenage sex; survey says parents are biggest influence on teens' decisions about whether to engage in sex, but do not realize it; other results noted (M)
docs.snippet: Adults are far more likely than their children to think that it is embarrassing for teenagers to admit to being virgins, and in fact teenagers wish their parents were a bit bolder in advising them about whether to have sex, according to a national...

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re the Personal Health column ''With Childbirth, Now It's What the Mother Orders'' (Dec. 9): The article raises concerns about the principle of convenience driving decisions to have surgery, which can invite a host of unintended consequences.
docs.abstract: Dr Tracy Willett letter about December 9 article on elective Caesareans discusses how women cope with complications of natural childbirth compared to surgical complications (S)
docs.snippet: To the Editor:     Re the Personal Health column ''With Childbirth, Now It's What the Mother Orders'' (Dec. 9): The article raises concerns about the principle of convenience driving decisions to have surgery, which can invite a host of unintended...

docs.lead_paragraph: The Assembly passed a bill on Monday that would make New Jersey the second state in the nation to permit embryonic stem cell research, a controversial practice that uses human cells and embryos to search for new treatments for Parkinson's disease, Alzheimer's and other illnesses. Although the federal government has restricted research on cells taken from embryos since 2001, New Jersey's measure would allow the state's pharmaceutical industry and biomedical laboratories to conduct an assortment of experiments that involve growing cells from embryos discarded at fertility clinics.

headline.main: Bill Allowing Stem Cell Work Clears New Jersey Assembly

docs.abstract: New Jersey Assembly passes bill to allow embryonic stem cell research; pharmaceutical companies and biomedical labs would be permitted to conduct experiments that involve growing cells from embryos discarded at fertility clinics; anti-abortion groups oppose measure; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''Debate on Selling Morning-After Pill Over the Counter'' (front page, Dec. 12): The level of support for switching Plan B emergency contraception from prescription to over-the-counter status is unprecedented and far outweighs the opposition.
docs.abstract: Letter from Dr Felicia H Stewart and Wayne C Shields argues in favor of switching Plan B emergency contraception from prescription to over-the-counter status; says decision should be based on medical evidence, not religious opposition (Dec 12 article)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Any woman considering an elective Caesarean should not only discuss the risks and benefits with her physician, as the article suggests, but should also spend some time with a woman who has just had one (''With Childbirth, Now It's What the Mother Orders'').
docs.abstract: Barbara Joan Grubman letter about December 9 article on elective Caesareans gives personal experience of undergoing two Caesareans (S)
